RESOLVED_ENTITIES.The United States Court of Appeals for t: The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit

AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Jose Marlon Ibarra-Zelaya: Defendant in a criminal case involving alien smuggling and hostage taking, sentenced to 292 months in prison, seeking relief from his sentence under Section 2255
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Nancy F. Atlas: Judge presiding over the case, who sentenced Jose Marlon Ibarra-Zelaya and is reviewing his claim for relief
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.the United States of America: Plaintiff in the case, opposing Jose Marlon Ibarra-Zelaya's motion for relief
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.illegal aliens: individuals being smuggled within the United States for commercial advantage and private financial gain, involved in a hostage-taking offense with between six and twenty-four aliens
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.foreign nationals: persons held for ransom and against their will
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.six co-defendants: co-defendants of Jose Marlon Ibarra-Zelaya found guilty as charged on all counts of the superseding indictment
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.five-count superseding indictment: indictment against Jose Marlon Ibarra-Zelaya and co-defendants, including charges related to hostage-taking and ransom demands
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Federal Grand Jury: jury that found Jose Marlon Ibarra-Zelaya and co-defendants guilty and returned a supplemental verdict
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.supplemental verdict: verdict returned by the United States Federal Grand Jury, finding that the hostage-taking offense involved between six and twenty-four aliens and a firearm
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Presentence Report: report prepared for determining punishment under the United States Sentencing Guidelines Manual
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.PSR: abbreviation for Presentence Report, used in determining sentence
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Sentencing Guidelines Manu: Manual used for determining sentence, considering the most serious offense among multiple counts, under which Jose Marlon Ibarra-Zelaya's sentence was calculated
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.the hostage-taking offense: offense involving between six and twenty-four aliens and a ransom demand, with a dangerous weapon used
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.the ransom demand: demand made in connection with the hostage-taking offense
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.the dangerous weapon: firearm brandished or otherwise used and possessed during the hostage-taking offense
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.the firearm: weapon used in connection with the hostage-taking offense
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.The United States Court of Appeals for t: court that affirmed Jose Marlon Ibarra-Zelaya's conviction and sentence
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.the United States Supreme Court: highest court in the United States, which could have been appealed to
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Adrian Almaguer: Attorney for Jose Marlon Ibarra-Zelaya, whose performance is being questioned in relation to ineffective assistance of counsel claims, specifically regarding failure to object to incorrect application of sentencing guidelines edition
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.pro se litigants: individuals representing themselves in a legal proceeding without an attorney
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.pro se pleadings: documents submitted by pro se litigants to the court
